answers.answer: Hi There,You might find a consultation with a reproductive endocrinologist helpful.  Polycystic ovarian syndrome PCOS is part of a hormonal constellation that includes insulin resistance (which leads to diabetes).The diagnosis is made on the basis of history - irregular or no periodsexam - increased male pattern facial and body hairultrasound - multiple small cysts in the ovarieslabs - a hormone profilebest wishes

question: I hadn't had a period for 5 months. My youngest child will be 2 yrs. old on 3/28/08. I went to the Dr. and had labs done.  They were all within normal limits.  I was put on ortho tri lo to helpwith the no period issue.  A coupel weeks later, i went in to have a what they thought was a skin  tag removed.  Turns out to be an ordinary mole.  Anyways, I asked if there was something wrong with me because I had gained 40 lbs in 1 year.  The Dr. flipped through my labs and my chart, and simply siad you have PCOS.  i was told that if I take Metformin it will helpe to lose the weight and control the symptoms of PCOS.  Well, the only time I have a period is when i am taking the "pill",and the Metformin give me the "poops" really bad.  I have had no tests to confirm PCOS.  Are there any out there?  And an other quick question...When i had my second child i had gestational diabetes.  When i delivered her naturally, it too an hour for the midwife to deliver the placenta.  She had her arm inside of me up to her elbow it seemed like.  Could tht have caused some sort of problem?  i guess there were hard calcified spots on it from the diabetes and that is why it wouldnt come loose.  Any advice you offer would be a great help.
